caption: It is always a great collection, and much like the Louvre, you could spend days there learning and experiencing great art.  I found a new unexpected top 10 painting there that just makes me laugh inside! It is so nice to find a moving piece of art.

Unparalleled collection of paintings, it is a stunning museum! People here have appreciated many paintings or sculptures by world-renowned masters... As a cultural heritage of humanity, these works leave a lasting impression and make me reluctant to leave this museum! In addition, what I want to say is that the staff here are also very friendly and professional, which is very satisfying and in line with the atmosphere of these great works

I love the museum so much üò≠ impressionists are stunning. Sculptures are amazing. Museum has 2 cafes, 1 is on the top level, me t to the watch, I recommend you having a coffee there in case you want one. Waiting line was pretty long, about 20mins.

This is one of the best museums especially for romantic and impressionist works. The building itself is a standout and the video at the lower ground entrance worth watching to get some history. Spread over 5 levels the collection has iconic works by well known artists; Degas, Manet, Monet , Van Gogh and the list goes on. The sculptures are amazing and the art nouveau rooms and furniture a real knockout. The Clock Cafe on level 5 has amazing decor and the clock of course. The coffee was absolutely awful. Weak watery and only warm. The tart was good. I think this museum is second only to the Louvre.

I recently visited the Mus√©e d‚ÄôOrsay in Paris, and it was absolutely beautiful. I highly recommend it if you‚Äôre in the city. Personally, I enjoyed it even more than the Louvre. You don‚Äôt necessarily need to reserve tickets in advance, as the queue wasn‚Äôt too long. The museum, housed in a historic train station, has stunning architecture and a fascinating history. Inside, you‚Äôll find incredible art from masters like Van Gogh and Monet, as well as impressive sculptures. The atmosphere and the iconic clock inside make it an unforgettable experience.

A lovely experience here. The audio guide was actually quite useful to learn a bit more about the exhibition you are seeing. Clear and logical layout of the museum and lots of interesting pieces. Staff were friendly.

I love this museum. The architecture is absolutely beautiful as are the works of art it houses. The impressionist wing boasts a huge collection and the paintings are stunning. Monet‚Äôs waterlilies and Van Gogh‚Äôs starry night can be found here. There is also a very impressive miniature of the Opera Garnier on the ground floor. Allow half a day here as there‚Äôs lots to see. I highly recommend buying tickets online to skip the long queues.

The Mus√©e d‚ÄôOrsay is an absolute must-see in Paris! I loved every moment of my visit‚Äîit‚Äôs a fantastic museum that offers an unforgettable experience. Housed in a beautifully restored Beaux-Arts railway station, the building itself is a masterpiece, perfectly complementing the breathtaking collection inside.  The museum boasts an incredible selection of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist works, featuring masterpieces by Monet, Van Gogh, Degas, Renoir, and so many more. Walking through its galleries felt like stepping into an art lover‚Äôs dream, with iconic paintings around every corner. The layout is spacious and well-organized, allowing you to fully appreciate each piece without feeling overwhelmed.  One of the highlights for me was the stunning view of Paris through the giant clock window‚Äîan experience in itself! Whether you‚Äôre an art enthusiast or just a casual visitor, the Mus√©e d‚ÄôOrsay is an unmissable gem. If you‚Äôre in Paris, this museum should be at the top of your list!

I could spend days here just like at The Louvre.  We had a guide and it made a big difference.   He pointed out several art works that had just gone on display.  They loan them Out to other museums in trade for new ones.   I really like the chronological approach to the art work.   It lets you lead and see how the art changed over time due to politics, governments, social norms and previous artist‚Äôs works.

Our third attempt to visit this Musee and finally got to visit. Big open concept building that was a train station at one time. The top floor has many works of art from the well-known artist.  This building has a well-known clock that has an awesome view of Paris. It's a must do when in Paris.

I had a lovely visit to the museum. I would recommend purchasing the audio guided tour. There is signage throughout the museum indicating when there is an audio file associated with a painting. I particularly enjoyed this on the top floor (Impressionism, Van Gogh, etc). This was likely off season, but the museum was still busy. Be prepared to compete with crowds. I recommend buying tickets to any museum/attraction in advance, as those with and without tickets enter through different lines.

This museum was not on our list of places to go but we ended up here because we finished our visit to the Louvre with plenty of time to spare.  I have to say that this was probably the highlight of my trip. We saw more artists and art that spoke to us on one floor here than on the rest of our trip combined.  Amazing art, getting to see Van Gogh, Monet, Degas, Manet, Renoir and so much more. Up close without the crazy crowds. Just amazing.

A great experience.  Walked in a bit early and they welcomed us immediately. Unlike Versailles and Louvre where they insist on a half hour wait in line. Through the turnstiles. Into a magnificent space with natural light filtering through the skylights onto the statues. A logical progression through the decades with all of the favourite artists of year Impressionist era, plus some others.

Really enjoyed this museum, free if you are under 25 and a resident in the EU! Very well organized and not overwhelming. The audio guide was very, very interesting and again not overwhelming with only major important pieces of art highlighted. This made the museum feel incredibly manageable. In a gorgeous old train station and many good views of the city from the upper level exhibits.

Great museum with tons of amazing art to see, including some really famous pieces. It's a big house but not as overwhelming as the Louvre. If you love art, plan to spend a few hours. There are queues if you don't buy your tickets in advance.

What a beautiful experience this was. The building, the exhibits, the atmosphere. Simply wonderful. A perfect alternative to the queues (and crowds!!) at the Louvre.  Buy advanced tickets to save queuing outside (we bought ours two goes before arriving on their website).  As this was a former railway station, it tickles art enthusiasts and train enthusiasts alike. The architecture is stunning.  Central location, easy to get to, and 100% worth a visit.

So many great things to see here including the architecture of this former railway station. Works by Seurat, Monet, Degas and many more are set out well. An iconic building with a wealth of exhibits. Looking forward to returning.

Best museum. I love it so much. I've been here +3 times now and it's never a dull experience. The sculpture hallway is magnificent and every piece of art is amazing. No other museum has dethroned this one for me so far.

Mus√©e d'Orsay is absolutely stunning! The collection of Impressionist art is breathtaking, and the building itself is beautiful. It‚Äôs best to book tickets in advance and arrive early to avoid crowds. A must-visit for art lovers‚Äîtruly an unforgettable experience in Paris!

A stunning museum showcasing an incredible collection of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist masterpieces. The building, a former railway station, adds to the charm with its grand architecture. Perfect for art lovers and a must-visit in Paris!

Very beautiful museum. There was a bit of a line up but I suggest booking your ticket for the date up front for a faster entry. We LOVED the fact that it had complementary lockers for visitors‚Ä¶ I have never seen it and it was super convenient.

We found it easier to go without reservation. There was no queue with the museum pass. With security check we were inside in under 5 min. All the ladies bathrooms had a 15-20min wait time. Top floor most popular.
No need to book in advance, just go buy ticket in the museum when you go during the week. The que is pretty short. Go to fifth floor, have nice breakfast then go have a look at van gogh's arts.

Absolutely stunning museum. Having been to Paris 6 times it was my first time visiting here and I instantly regretted not having visited sooner.  My 2.5 hours did not feel long enough and you can easily spend half a day here, if not more. I actually loved it more than the Louvre. If you love the impressionist era of paintings this is for you as the collection of Van Gogh, Monet, Renoir and more is incredible. I was also particularly impressed with the painting collection from the Orient. Very vast and beautiful.  I am removing one star (although it pains me to) because the management of the queue on Tuesday the 25th of February in the heavy downpour was abysmal and the worst queue management I have seen ever. I had pre booked a ticket and it seemed to make no difference and I still ended up queueing for over an hour and ended up being soaking wet through to my socks. So walking around the museum in wet socks was not my ideal way to explore so I ended up having to leave early. I felt particularly bad for young children, many of whom were shivering with cold and were not let in despite being there on time.  Please have better management of the queue especially in difficult weather. There were hardly any employees dotted around the queue as they should have been and instead they were concentrated in one place and even then just two of them, which as you can see from the photo was just not enough.  That being said, despite my squishy feet, I was so happy to have seen Starry Night.

Lovely museum. We chose to walk around without the audio guide. So many pieces to look at, I'd have to go back to see them all. We were there after Christmas and it was very busy. They have FREE lockers to put your jackets in, or anything else you don't want to carry. We didn't have to wait long to get in, we already had purchased tickets. Also my mother in law had a cane and they put us through quickly through the queue

This was by far my Favorite museum of the ones we visited in Paris. A huge exhibit within the old Train Station, itself a fine, ornate, historic building in and of itself. The station clock still rests on one of the walls. Rooms on all side depict different painting styles and masters with a few rare oddities (subject facing the painter, other once taboo images), while the concourse is filled with statues, including a small draft version of Rodin's Gates to Hell (Dante's Inferno). There is a restaurant on the roof and access to the outer terrace which has statues itself, and views across the Seine to the Louvre, and up to Sacre Coeur, as well as another giant clock face. I would gladly go again and wander all the galleries a second time.

Honestly I think this museum is better than the louvre in terms of what it has to offer for fans of Van Gogh and Monet.. it‚Äôs smaller but still grand at the same time and worth every penny and second.. you can buy a combo ticket with another museum.. I did that instead of a single ticket

A beautiful museum and one of my favorite stops in Paris. A must-see if you‚Äôve never been. It‚Äôs best to purchase tickets in advance, but if you can‚Äôt get them, just get there early and get in line. We were able to get in on a Saturday with no advance tickets.

A wonderful and beautiful museum. It felt very well designed and you‚Äôd almost think it was intended to be a museum. The train station history behind the museum was very fun to learn about and the art was also great. 5/5 phenomenal museum

This is a great museum. It has many beautiful and famous sculptures and paintings. The building is also very beautiful. You will find famous Van Gogh paintings too It will take around 2 hrs to visit the whole museum.  Do visit this museum if you want to cover another museum in Paris after the Louvre (BTW this is located near Louvre). Book tickets in advance if you are visiting over the weekend or on holidays.

Impressionists heaven! The Orsay is THE place to view impressionist art! I only had one day in Paris and this was my must-see museum which did not disappoint. I‚Äôve visited the Orsay five times before this trip, but never by myself. Despite, the numerous people due to the Louvre closure that day, leisurely explored the different galleries to enjoy the art. Unfortunately, the beautiful restaurant on the second floor was closed, offering me the opportunity to visit the ornate ballroom which was very beautiful. TIP-purchase a Fast Track and skip the lines!

I always santed to visit this museum as I live impressionism and this is the perfect place to admire its masterpieces. Booked tickets on line for a specific time slot. However rooms were so crouded that you could not walk or even breath! So it would be good to control better the number  of visitors per time slot. It could advance the overall experience

I went in an hour before the museum closed on the Paris Museum Card. They let me in without waiting in line. The museum is huge, I didn't have time to see everything. I want to go back and see all the exhibits there properly. The museum hall itself fascinates me, it's an old train station that was converted into a museum a long time ago.

We enjoyed the visit at this museum, that was Formerly a train station. The size was just right. Astonishing masterpieces üé® some of the paintings fill a whole room ü§©  Interesting to read the story of each painter for example Gaugin and van Gogh.  Highly recommended üëçüèΩ üòÄ

One of my favorite museums ever, probably my favorite in Paris. Less overwhelming than the Louvre, and with a good amount of absolute bangers. If you are only going for a quick visit, go right to the top floor to view their impressionism collection. bonne journ√©e!

The Mus√©e d‚ÄôOrsay is a true gem in Paris! Housed in a beautifully restored former train station, it offers an extraordinary collection of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist masterpieces. From Monet and Van Gogh to Degas and Renoir, every gallery is a feast for the eyes. The museum‚Äôs layout is intuitive, and the spacious design allows for a comfortable viewing experience, even on busy days. The clock windows provide stunning views of the Seine and Paris, adding to the charm of the visit. The staff is friendly, and the audio guides enhance the experience with rich insights. A must-visit for art lovers and anyone seeking a cultural highlight in Paris!

Beautiful museum showcasing extraordinary art. Particularly enjoyed the impressionist art. Many of the works are much larger than I had thought they would be! Added to their grandeur. This is a must if you are in Paris.  We arrived at 4pm on a Friday, and there was no line at the security.  We only had until 6pm to look around but it was pretty empty and easy to see most of the art. They starting closing some of the rooms and areas before 6pm so be mindful of that.

Queue for ticket and non ticket holders are the same, long queue. It was raining and no shades at all for the queue, stood under the rain for 10+ minutes. The impressionist arts are great, especially Monet and Van Gogh section at level 5; but also where the main crowds are. The entire viewing experience isn‚Äôt a good as Louvre, I felt cramped, squeezed and stuffy despite the same amount of crowd.
